directed by Michael Apted 56 up is the
latest installment in his long-running
documentary project where he visits a
group of Britons every 7 years and
produces a film about their lives in her
review Manohla Dargis writes what gives
the up series its punch is less its
longevity or the human spectacle it
offers but that these are moving images
of touchingly vibrant lives at certain
moments in time and space watching them
is like peering into a memory machine
one that inevitably summons up your own
reminiscences it's fascinating to listen
to the participants mull over the series
and their own roles in it over the years
some have felt misrepresented aggrieved
and at times angry and yet for all the
reservations they showed up and open
mouths hearts Holmes answer those kind
of questions versus Antony's gone
extremely quickly we've just come
together but I think you really notice
it I mean you still think you the sign
it's when maybe when you pull a muscle
that just reminds you that you're
getting all that always lost on the

solace from the semi-autobiographical
novel by Jack Kerouac on the road
follows two young beatniks as the
crisscross post-war America in his
review Stephen Holden writes if there is
little to actively dislike about on the
road there is a great deal to be
disappointed on Clara wax novel is
really a romantic pian to a charismatic
madman told by his worshipful acolyte
and chronicled in the book character
development and storytelling are
secondary to blasts of supercharged
writing that is the literary equivalent
of jazz improvisation but because so
little of that language is in the film
south paradise based on Kerouac himself
emerges as an earnest passive almost
drivi disciple more concerned with
gathering material for a novel than was
living high in the moment it all seems
of little consequence
